Based on the provided context and sources, it appears that ancient civilizations, including ancient India and ancient Rome, did have toilets or latrines. In ancient India, toilets were simple holes in the ground or seats over pits, dating back to around 2500 BCE in the Indus Valley Civilization.

In ancient Rome, toilets were more advanced and often found in public bathhouses. The Romans developed a system of sewers and public toilets, known as latrinae, which were typically benches with holes over drains. The waste was often discharged into the Tiber River or other waterways.
